title: How to Get Your Eight Glasses of Water a Day

steps.title: Measure out how much water you'll need each day.
steps.content: Measure out how much water you'll need each day. 2 liters (0.5 US gal) is about 8 glasses of water. Having a container that size may help you remember to drink enough water every day. If you have an empty 2-liter soda bottle, fill it with water and put it in your fridge. Drink the entire bottle of water over the course of the day. If you are not drinking the entire bottle of water each day, you may not be getting enough water.

steps.title: Make it a habit.
steps.content: Make it a habit. Train yourself to drink a glass of water every morning when you first wake up, a glass when you get home from work or school, and a glass every evening right before bed. That's three of your eight recommended daily glasses. You can make a daily water chart to help you get started, and after a while, the practice will feel like second nature. Drinking water in the morning also helps jump-start your metabolism, and is a refreshing way to wake up every day. [3] X Research source There are also water bottles on the market with counting systems worked into their design. For instance, some bottles have a little dial that is turned each time 8 oz is drank. This encourages more water consumption.

steps.title: Drink water when you're distracted.
steps.content: Drink water when you're distracted. Another habit to cultivate is sipping a glass of water while you're doing other work, whether on the computer or watching TV. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Download an app.
steps.content: Download an app. There are many apps available for your smartphone that can help you keep track of how much water you've drunk, or give you reminders to drink more. Many are free, but if you pay for one, you might be more motivated to use it on a daily basis. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Buy a water bottle you'll love.
steps.content: Buy a water bottle you'll love. Carry your bottle everywhere you go. Not only will it reduce the number of disposable water bottles you go through, it may also motivate you to use your new bottle. Remember to use a water bottle that not only looks nice, feels nice and keeps your water cold, but also one that is BPA free and easily washable.

steps.title: Know your environment and your activity levels.
steps.content: Know your environment and your activity levels. Health professionals will often advise you to drink more water than usual (which can mean more than 8 glasses a day), depending on environmental factors. If you live in a hot, dry climate, you'll probably need to drink more water than someone who lives in an arctic climate. And if you're exercising, you'll need even more water to stay hydrated. Don't wait until you're thirsty to drink water, especially if you're engaging in physical activity and/or if the weather is hot. By the time you feel thirsty, your body is already dehydrated. steps.title: If you feel hungry, drink water first.
steps.content: If you feel hungry, drink water first. This will make you fuller before you eat, and may even stave off cravings, as thirst is often mistaken for hunger. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Drink carbonated water.
steps.content: Drink carbonated water. The bubbles give ordinary water an extra sparkle, and if you drink flavored seltzer, you may even be able to trick your brain into thinking it's soda. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Freeze your water the night before.
steps.content: Freeze your water the night before. As the ice melts you can sip on an ice-cold bottle of water all day. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Add fruit.
steps.content: Add fruit. Slicing up citrus, berries, or even cucumbers into your water will give it a zesty, fresh taste that will keep you coming back for more.

steps.title: Make flavored ice cubes.
steps.content: Make flavored ice cubes. You can freeze just about any juice, mashed up fruit, or even coffee or flavored tea in an ice cube tray. When they're ready, pop out a few cubes and add them to your water bottle. [10] X Research source
